triples.name: Boolean satisfiability problem
triples.relevance: SAT is the central problem that connects logic, complexity theory, and practical solving techniques discussed throughout the handbook.

triples.name: Model checking
triples.relevance: A key verification technique that uses SAT solvers for checking hardware and software specifications against formal properties.

triples.name: Bounded Model Checking
triples.relevance: A practical variant of model checking that addresses state explosion by bounding the search and encoding the problem as SAT instances.

triples.name: Boolean algebra
triples.relevance: The mathematical foundation for Boolean formulas and logical operations used in SAT solving.

triples.name: Linear temporal logic
triples.relevance: A temporal logic used to specify properties of systems that are then verified using model checking and SAT-based techniques.

triples.name: Formal verification
triples.relevance: The overarching discipline that uses SAT solvers and related techniques to prove correctness of hardware and software systems.

triples.name: Hardware verification
triples.relevance: A major application area where SAT solvers and model checking techniques are essential for verifying hardware designs.

triples.name: Software verification
triples.relevance: A challenging verification domain where decision procedures and SAT solvers are used to verify software correctness.

triples.name: Bit array
triples.relevance: Bit-vectors are decision procedures for theories of bit-vectors used in program verification for languages with finite word-length integers.

triples.name: Integer programming
triples.relevance: Linear integer arithmetic is a theory for which decision procedures rely on SAT solvers for practical program verification.
